Award.AwardTitle: IRFP: The Function and Evolution of Terrestrial Reproduction
Award.AbstractNarration:
The International Research Fellowship Program enables U.S. scientists and engineers to conduct nine to twenty-four months of research abroad. The program's awards provide opportunities for joint research, and the use of unique or complementary facilities, expertise and experimental conditions abroad.

This award will support a twenty-four-month research fellowship by Dr. Justin C. Touchon to work with Drs. Harilaos Lessios and Roberto Iba√±ez at the Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute in Panama.

Understanding the evolution of life-history strategies is a central goal of evolutionary ecology. One of the most important life-history changes to evolve was the shift to living and reproducing on land by vertebrate animals. Frogs are particularly well-suited for studying this evolutionary shift because they were the first vertebrates to successfully invade land and there are numerous independent origins of terrestrial reproduction among frogs. This project uses a treefrog which can flexibly switch between laying aquatic and terrestrial eggs to study how the environment selects for aquatic and terrestrial reproduction. The treefrog Dendropsophus ebraccatus is found from Mexico to Colombia and across that range experiences over 8X variation in rainfall. Rain is particularly important, because it is the most important factor in determining if terrestrial eggs will survive. In addition, this research investigates reproduction in the species most closely related to D. ebraccatus to explore the transition from aquatic to terrestrial egg-laying across species. This project examines how selection has shaped aquatic and terrestrial reproduction throughout Central and South America.

This research addresses issues crucial to our understanding of how life on land evolved. The transition to reproducing on land is key to understanding the shift to terrestrial life and is arguably one of the most important in the history of life as a whole. In addition, this research is particularly timely because patterns of rainfall are currently changing, potentially altering selection on terrestrial amphibian eggs. This work will also address broadly general issues about how evolution moves between seemingly alternative strategies, such as laying eggs in water versus laying eggs on land.

This research will develop research collaborations in Panama, Costa Rica, Guatemala, Honduras, Nicaragua, Mexico, Belize, Colombia, Ecuador, Brazil and Peru, as well as providing research opportunities for undergraduates in each country. By using a group of especially interesting treefrogs to understand the evolution of terrestrial reproduction, this research will increase awareness of amphibians and their evolutionary and ecological importance.

POR.DRECONTENT:
One of the most important transitions to occur in the history of animals was the shift to living and reproducing on land by vertebrate animals, that is the shift from fish that live in water to frogs, reptiles, birds and mammals (including humans) that live primarily on land. Frogs are particularly well-suited for studying this evolutionary shift because they were the first vertebrate animals to successfully move to land. In addition, although most species of frogs lay eggs in water (like fish) many have evolved the ability to lay eggs out of water. This was not an event that occurred only once, but instead there are numerous separate origins of terrestrial egg-laying among frogs. Thus, frogs are particularly useful and interesting for studying the shift to breeding on land.

This project studied how the environment selects for aquatic and terrestrial reproduction by primarily focusing on a species of treefrog that can flexibly switch between laying aquatic or terrestrial eggs. The treefrog Dendropsophus ebraccatus is found from Mexico to Colombia and across that range experiences over 8X variation in rainfall. In addition, this project studied reproduction in the four species most closely related to D. ebraccatus to explore the transition from aquatic to terrestrial egg-laying across species. This project examines how selection has shaped aquatic and terrestrial reproduction throughout Central and South America. 

Studying a single population of D. ebraccatus in detail, I found that predators in water are what pushes an animal to breed on land, but that this push is countered by the risk of drying out when eggs are out of the water. These data also demonstrated the flexible reproduction in D. ebraccatus appears to be maintained by this balance between aquatic egg predation pressure and arboreal egg desiccation risk. In certain habitats, ones with more shade for example, the risk of eggs drying out on land decreases, making terrestrial egg-laying a better option than laying in water. However, when frogs are in ponds that do not have shade above them, the best course of action for frogs is to place their eggs in the water. Lastly, I analyzed 39 years of rainfall data from central Panama and found that rainfall patterns are changing in the Neotropics. I found that although the total amount of rain that falls each year has not changed, the number of days that actually receive rainfall when the frogs are breeding has decreased and the number of gaps rain storms has increased. The consequence of this for D. ebraccatus is that over the last 40 years, on average, laying eggs out of water has become less advantageous than laying them in water. For the first time in recent history, D. ebraccatus should lay eggs in the water in Gamboa to increase their survival.

 By studying multiple populations of D. ebraccatus from Mexico to Ecuador, I found that the evolutionary shift to laying eggs out of water is tied to the amount of rainfall different areas receive. In other words, in areas like Mexico where less rain falls, D. ebraccatus lays more of its eggs in the water than in areas like Ecuador or the Osa Peninsula of Costa Rica, where frogs lay all of their eggs out of the water all the time.
